div.p: with hydrogen as it can diffuse through the wax used to fix the capillary on the system. Several unknown decomposition products were not yet identified. The analysis of these different unknown phases are still in progress.

div.head: Mg(BH 4 ) 2 : NaNH 2
div.p: This system was studied in the same way as the parent Ca system. Four different mixtures from the reaction of two polymorphs of Mg(BH 4 ) 2 with NaNH 2 were studied. The formation of Na 3 N was also observed, showing evidence of NH 3 formation rather than H 2 . Unfortunately, for each experiment, the capillaries broke in the same way than in the Ca system. From the data analysis, we observed the formation of NaBH 4 and an unidentified compound. The identification of the latter is in process.

div.head: Study of the amorphous γ-Mg(BH 4 ) 2
div.p: From our last observations on the slow amorphization of γ-Mg(BH 4 ) 2 at room temperature in June 2012, a new study on the amorphous state obtained by compression was performed. The behavior of this freshly amorphous phase upon heating was unexpected. Indeed, a transformation from amorphous phase into crystalline γ-phase was observed at about 80°C then it decomposed in the same way than γ-phase. A paper on the amorphous γ-phase is in progress.

div.head: Reexamination of the decomposition pathway of γ-Mg(BH 4 ) 2 under H 2 back-pressure
div.p: Previous studies on the γ-Mg(BH 4 ) 2 decomposition under H 2 back-pressure showed a straightforward amorphization after few patterns. This time a fresh γ-Mg(BH 4 ) 2 was measured and for the first time, transformations through crystalline polymorphs into amorphous state were observed.

div.head: LiBH 4 and Ca(BH 4 ) 2 solid-state reactions with CO 2
div.p: The behavior of solid metal borohydrides with the presence of CO 2 is required further determination. During this experiment, we tried to observe the possible reactions between the representatives from alkali and alkali-earth borohydrides and CO 2 . The reaction evolution between LiBH 4 and CO 2 is not clear due to the bad quality of the starting LiBH 4 product. With Ca(BH 4 ) 2 and CO 2 , we observed typical phase transitions and decomposition products for this borohydride and a new phase with low intensity was found. The systems require further investigations.

div.head: Study of γ-Mg(BH 4 ) 2 under CO 2 back-pressure
div.p: The data analysis is in progress.

Mn(BH 4 ) 2 Mn(BH4) 2 is one of the possible precursors to synthesize bi-and tri-metallic borohydride systems, but the synthesis of pure Mn(BH 4 ) 2 itself is poorly characterized. We found that Mn 2 Li(BH 4 ) 5 •Et 2 O is an intermediate product in the reaction MnCl 2 + 2LiBH 4 -> Mn(BH4) 2 + 2 LiCl (in ether). Under vacuum this compound decomposed to Mn(BH 4 ) 2 and LiBH 4 . The data analysis is in progress.
[1] Jaron T., Grochala W. : Dalton Trans., 2011, 40, 12808
